intro: Ulmaria × purpurea, commonly known as the purple foamflower, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to eastern North America. It belongs to the family Polemoniaceae and is characterized by its hairy, low-growing stems and clusters of small, bell-shaped flowers. The plant typically produces violet or purple flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. Its leaves are opposite, ovate, and often covered with fine hairs, contributing to its distinctive appearance. Ulmaria × purpurea thrives in shady, moist environments and is often found in woodland areas.
